https://www.eleken.co/blog-posts/bad-ux-.agent_response: Here’s the consolidated accessibility assessment for the requested page: URL: https://www.eleken.co/blog-posts/bad-ux-examples WCAG grade: A Compliance score: 81/100 Automated issues (summary): • Missing or empty element (WCAG 2.4.2) • No H1 heading found (WCAG 2.4.6) • No “Skip to main content” link (WCAG 2.4.1) • All other checks (images, links, forms, buttons, headings, tables, lists, focus management, landmarks, color contrast, touch targets, media controls) passed or are not applicable. AI-driven insights & recommendations (focused on developer needs): 1. Page structure & landmarks – Add a meaningful <title> in the <head> (e.g., “12 Bad UX Examples – Expert Analysis | Eleken”). – Ensure exactly one <h1> at the top of the article (e.g., the blog post title). – Include a “Skip to main content” link at the top for keyboard users. 2. Headings hierarchy – Use <h1> for the page title, <h2> for major sections, <h3> for subsections, etc. – This helps screen readers and assists with logical navigation. 3. Color & contrast (even if no text failed): – Verify all text-overlay and link-hover colors meet a 4.5:1 contrast ratio. – Run WebAIM or Lighthouse checks for each color combination. 4. Alt text & non-text content – Although no images were flagged by the basic scan, manually confirm that every <img> (including decorative and content images) has an appropriate alt attribute: • Informational images need descriptive alt text. • Decorative images should have alt="". 5. Keyboard & focus – Add clear focus styles (outline or underline) on interactive elements (links, buttons). – Ensure all custom controls (e.g., TOC items, video overlays) are keyboard-accessible (use tabindex, ARIA where needed). 6. ARIA and landmarks – Use landmark roles (header, nav, main, footer) or HTML5 semantic tags. – Ensure dynamic content (e.g., expanding FAQ accordions) updates ARIA-expanded on controls. 7. Testing steps – Re-run automated scans (Lighthouse, axe-core). – Perform manual keyboard navigation and screen-reader testing (NVDA/VoiceOver). – Validate on mobile devices for touch-target size and orientation. Next steps 1. Prioritize the missing <title>, H1, and skip link—critical for navigation. 2. Refine headings and ensure semantic structure. 3. Conduct contrast, alt text, and keyboard tests. Missing alt attributes on images • Guideline: 1.1.1 Non-text Content • Fix: Add descriptive alt="" on decorative images or alt="…" on content images. • Example: <img src="image.jpg" alt="Description of the image"> Additional improvement suggestions: - Keyboard navigation: ensure all interactive controls (links/buttons/forms) are keyboard-focusable; use tabindex if needed. - Form labels: associate <label> elements with each form control for screen readers. Developer checklist: - [ ] Verify and add alt text to all images. - [ ] Check and adjust color contrast ratios. - [ ] Add a meaningful <title>. - [ ] Include exactly one H1 at the top of the main content. - [ ] Insert a “Skip to main content” link. Recommended testing: - Automated audits (e.g., Axe, Lighthouse). - Manual testing with screen readers (NVDA, JAWS) and keyboard-only navigation.

AI Analysis Insights  
• Overall compliance is good, but key navigational and structural deficits hinder screen-reader and keyboard users.  
• The lack of an H1 prevents clear page landmarking.  
• Missing skip link requires users to tab through lengthy nav before reaching main content.

Recommendations

• Implement a “Skip to main content” link as the first focusable element.  
• Verify and adjust text/background color combinations for adequate contrast.  
• Confirm all interactive elements (tabs, buttons) are reachable and operable via keyboard.  
• Ensure images and media include descriptive alt text.
